required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of RO7239361 in Ambulatory Boys With Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Double Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Study to Assess the Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of RO7239361 in Ambulatory Boys With Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

brief_summary.textblock: This is a multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to assess the efficacy, safety and tolerability of two different weekly doses of RO7239361 in ambulatory boys with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD).

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Baseline for the North Star Ambulatory Assessment (NSAA) Total Score
primary_outcome.description: The NSAA is a functional scale specifically designed for ambulant boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) that can provide information about motor function. The NSAA is a 17-item test of standing, ability to transition from lying to sitting, sitting to standing, and other mobility assessments. Each of the 17 items is evaluated on an ordinal scale of 0-2: 0 = unable to achieve independently, 1 = modified method but achieves goal independent of physical assistance from another, or 2 = normal with no obvious modification of activity. Total score range is 0 to 34. Higher scores reflect better performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in the North Star Ambulatory Assessment (NSAA) Total Score at Week 48
primary_outcome.description: The NSAA is a functional scale specifically designed for ambulant boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) that can provide information about motor function. The NSAA is a 17-item test of standing, ability to transition from lying to sitting, sitting to standing, and other mobility assessments. Each of the 17 items is evaluated on an ordinal scale of 0-2: 0 = unable to achieve independently, 1 = modified method but achieves goal independent of physical assistance from another, or 2 = normal with no obvious modification of activity. Total score range is 0 to 34. Higher scores reflect better performance. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).

secondary_outcome.description: The time to complete the 4 stair climb was measured at baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in 4 Stair Climb Velocity (4SCV)
secondary_outcome.description: 4SCV was calculated as the ratio of the number of stairs climbed (4) divided by the number of seconds taken to complete the 4-stair climb. The results were converted into velocity (distance/time). A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline for the Time to Stand From Supine
secondary_outcome.description: The time required for a participant to stand from supine position. A longer time reflects a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in Stand From Supine Velocity
secondary_outcome.description: The time required for a participant to stand from supine position. A longer time reflects a worse outcome. A negative change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).
The time required for a participant to run or walk a distance of 10 meters as quickly as possible. A longer time reflects a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in 10 M Walk/Run Velocity
secondary_outcome.description: The time required for a participant to run or walk a distance of 10 meters as quickly as possible calculated as velocity (distance/time). A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline for the Pediatric Outcome Data Collection Instrument (PODCI) Transfer and Basic Mobility Subscale
secondary_outcome.description: The PODCI is designed to be completed by the parent/guardian of a child who has knowledge of the child's conditions. The Transfer and Basic Mobility scale is one of the subscales of the PODCI. The results are standardized into a scale of 0-100 with a higher score reflecting better performance.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in Pediatric Outcome Data Collection Instrument (PODCI) Transfer and Basic Mobility Subscale
secondary_outcome.description: The PODCI is designed to be completed by the parent/guardian of a child who has knowledge of the child's conditions. The Transfer and Basic Mobility scale is one of the subscales of the PODCI. The results are standardized into a scale of 0-100 with a higher score reflecting better performance. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in Proximal Lower Extremity Flexor Strength
secondary_outcome.description: Proximal lower extremity flexor (knee extension and knee flexion) strength was measured using manual myometry. A higher score reflects a better outcome. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline for the 6 Minute Walk Distance (6MWD)
secondary_outcome.description: The 6MWD measured the distance a participant was able to traverse while walking for 6 minutes. A longer distance reflects a better outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in 6 Minute Walk Distance (6MWD)
secondary_outcome.description: The 6MWD measured the distance a participant was able to traverse while walking for 6 minutes. A longer distance reflects a better outcome. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants for Each Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGI-C) Assessment Status at Week 48
secondary_outcome.description: The CGI-C was used to assess the participant's overall condition on a 7-point scale, using the status markers "very much improved, much improved, slightly improved, no change, slightly worse, much worse or very much worse" at Week 48 as compared to baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in 95th Percentile Stride Velocity
secondary_outcome.description: Stride velocity was recorded with the ActiMyo device in a subset of the overall study population. The ActiMyo device measures the daily movement and activity levels of the participant. The device consists of two sensors worn on each ankle. A higher velocity reflects a better outcome. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events (AEs)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During DB period (48 weeks) and Whole study (up to approximately 34 months)
secondary_outcome.description: An adverse event is any untoward medical occurrence in a subject administered a pharmaceutical product and which does not necessarily have to have a causal relationship with the treatment. An adverse event can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding, for example), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a pharmaceutical product, whether or not considered related to the pharmaceutical product. Preexisting conditions which worsen during a study are also considered as adverse events.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With AEs Leading to Discontinuation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During DB period (48 weeks) and Whole study (up to approximately 34 months)
secondary_outcome.description: An adverse event is any untoward medical occurrence in a subject administered a pharmaceutical product and which does not necessarily have to have a causal relationship with the treatment. An adverse event can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding, for example), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a pharmaceutical product, whether or not considered related to the pharmaceutical product. Preexisting conditions which worsen during a study are also considered as adverse events. Reported here is the number of participants with AEs that led to study discontinuation.

arm_group.description: Participants received low dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received low dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

Participants received high dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

Participants received matching placebo solution subcutaneously (SC) on specified days of the 48-week double-blind (DB) period. Following the DB period participants received low dose or high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

intervention.description: Take RO7239361 subcutaneously on specified days over a 48 week blinded period
Take placebo subcutaneously on specified days over a 48 week blinded period

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosed with DMD by confirmed medical history and genetic testing
- Able to walk without assistance
- Minimum North Star Ambulatory Assessment score of 15 at screening
- Able to walk up 4 stairs in 8 seconds or less
- Weigh at least 15 kg (33 lbs)
- Taking corticosteroids for DMD
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any behavior or mental issue that will affect the ability to complete the required study procedures
- Previously or currently taking medications like androgens or human growth hormone
- Use of a ventilator during the day
- Unable to have blood samples collected or receive an injection under the skin
- Concomitant or previous participation at any time in a gene therapy study
Other protocol defined Inclusion/Exclusion Criteria could apply.

group.description: Participants received matching placebo solution subcutaneously (SC) on specified days of the 48-week double-blind (DB) period. Following the DB period participants received low dose or high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

participants_list.participants: Double-blind (DB) placebo participants switched to RO7239361 (RO) for the open label phase.
14 DB placebo participants switched to the RO Low Dose for the open-label phase.
13 DB placebo participants switched to the RO High Dose for the open-label phase.

outcome.description: The NSAA is a functional scale specifically designed for ambulant boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) that can provide information about motor function. The NSAA is a 17-item test of standing, ability to transition from lying to sitting, sitting to standing, and other mobility assessments. Each of the 17 items is evaluated on an ordinal scale of 0-2: 0 = unable to achieve independently, 1 = modified method but achieves goal independent of physical assistance from another, or 2 = normal with no obvious modification of activity. Total score range is 0 to 34. Higher scores reflect better performance.
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment.

measure.title: Baseline for the North Star Ambulatory Assessment (NSAA) Total Score
measure.description: The NSAA is a functional scale specifically designed for ambulant boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) that can provide information about motor function. The NSAA is a 17-item test of standing, ability to transition from lying to sitting, sitting to standing, and other mobility assessments. Each of the 17 items is evaluated on an ordinal scale of 0-2: 0 = unable to achieve independently, 1 = modified method but achieves goal independent of physical assistance from another, or 2 = normal with no obvious modification of activity. Total score range is 0 to 34. Higher scores reflect better performance.
measure.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in the North Star Ambulatory Assessment (NSAA) Total Score at Week 48
outcome.description: The NSAA is a functional scale specifically designed for ambulant boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) that can provide information about motor function. The NSAA is a 17-item test of standing, ability to transition from lying to sitting, sitting to standing, and other mobility assessments. Each of the 17 items is evaluated on an ordinal scale of 0-2: 0 = unable to achieve independently, 1 = modified method but achieves goal independent of physical assistance from another, or 2 = normal with no obvious modification of activity. Total score range is 0 to 34. Higher scores reflect better performance. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment. MMRM analysis included all participants at baseline and the following number of participants by Week 48: Placebo n=30, Low Dose n=29, High Dose n=33.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in the North Star Ambulatory Assessment (NSAA) Total Score at Week 48
measure.description: The NSAA is a functional scale specifically designed for ambulant boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) that can provide information about motor function. The NSAA is a 17-item test of standing, ability to transition from lying to sitting, sitting to standing, and other mobility assessments. Each of the 17 items is evaluated on an ordinal scale of 0-2: 0 = unable to achieve independently, 1 = modified method but achieves goal independent of physical assistance from another, or 2 = normal with no obvious modification of activity. Total score range is 0 to 34. Higher scores reflect better performance. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).
measure.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment. MMRM analysis included all participants at baseline and the following number of participants by Week 48: Placebo n=30, Low Dose n=29, High Dose n=33.

analysis.estimate_desc: Based on the MMRM using an unstructured covariance matrix -change = Baseline + Age Interactive response system (IXRS) Stratum + Corticosteroid Regimen IXRS Stratum + Analysis Visit*Treatment.
Based on the MMRM using an unstructured covariance matrix -change = Baseline + Age IXRS Stratum + Corticosteroid Regimen IXRS Stratum + Analysis Visit*Treatment.

measure.title: Baseline for the Pediatric Outcome Data Collection Instrument (PODCI) Transfer and Basic Mobility Subscale
measure.description: The PODCI is designed to be completed by the parent/guardian of a child who has knowledge of the child's conditions. The Transfer and Basic Mobility scale is one of the subscales of the PODCI. The results are standardized into a scale of 0-100 with a higher score reflecting better performance.
measure.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in Pediatric Outcome Data Collection Instrument (PODCI) Transfer and Basic Mobility Subscale
outcome.description: The PODCI is designed to be completed by the parent/guardian of a child who has knowledge of the child's conditions. The Transfer and Basic Mobility scale is one of the subscales of the PODCI. The results are standardized into a scale of 0-100 with a higher score reflecting better performance. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment. MMRM analysis included all participants at baseline and the following number of participants by Week 48: Placebo n=31, Low Dose n=29, High Dose n=34.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo solution subcutaneously (SC) on specified days of the 48-week double-blind (DB) period. Following the DB period participants received low dose or high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

group.title: RO7239361 Low Dose
group.description: Participants received low dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received low dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

group.title: RO7239361 High Dose
group.description: Participants received high dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

measure.title: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in Pediatric Outcome Data Collection Instrument (PODCI) Transfer and Basic Mobility Subscale
measure.description: The PODCI is designed to be completed by the parent/guardian of a child who has knowledge of the child's conditions. The Transfer and Basic Mobility scale is one of the subscales of the PODCI. The results are standardized into a scale of 0-100 with a higher score reflecting better performance. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).
measure.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment. MMRM analysis included all participants at baseline and the following number of participants by Week 48: Placebo n=31, Low Dose n=29, High Dose n=34.

analysis.estimate_desc: Based on the MMRM using an unstructured covariance matrix - change = Baseline + Age IXRS Stratum + Corticosteroid Regimen IXRS Stratum + Analysis Visit*Treatment.
Based on the MMRM using an unstructured covariance matrix - change = Baseline + Age IXRS Stratum + Corticosteroid Regimen IXRS Stratum + Analysis Visit*Treatment.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in Proximal Lower Extremity Flexor Strength
outcome.description: Proximal lower extremity flexor (knee extension and knee flexion) strength was measured using manual myometry. A higher score reflects a better outcome. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement.
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment. Number analyzed is the number of participants with data available for analyses at the given timepoint.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo solution subcutaneously (SC) on specified days of the 48-week double-blind (DB) period. Following the DB period participants received low dose or high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

group.title: RO7239361 Low Dose
group.description: Participants received low dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received low dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

group.title: RO7239361 High Dose
group.description: Participants received high dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

measure.title: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in Proximal Lower Extremity Flexor Strength
measure.description: Proximal lower extremity flexor (knee extension and knee flexion) strength was measured using manual myometry. A higher score reflects a better outcome. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement.
measure.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment. Number analyzed is the number of participants with data available for analyses at the given timepoint.

class.title: Change from Baseline at Week 48: Knee Extenders
Change from Baseline at Week 48: Knee Flexors

outcome.title: Baseline for the 6 Minute Walk Distance (6MWD)
outcome.description: The 6MWD measured the distance a participant was able to traverse while walking for 6 minutes. A longer distance reflects a better outcome.
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo solution subcutaneously (SC) on specified days of the 48-week double-blind (DB) period. outcome.description: The 6MWD measured the distance a participant was able to traverse while walking for 6 minutes. A longer distance reflects a better outcome. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement. Based on the mixed-effect model of repeated measures (MMRM).

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants for Each Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGI-C) Assessment Status at Week 48
outcome.description: The CGI-C was used to assess the participant's overall condition on a 7-point scale, using the status markers "very much improved, much improved, slightly improved, no change, slightly worse, much worse or very much worse" at Week 48 as compared to baseline.
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment. Included in the analysis are only those subjects for whom an efficacy assessment was completed at Week 48.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo solution subcutaneously (SC) on specified days of the 48-week double-blind (DB) period. Following the DB period participants received low dose or high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

group.title: RO7239361 Low Dose
group.description: Participants received low dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received low dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

group.title: RO7239361 High Dose
group.description: Participants received high dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants for Each Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGI-C) Assessment Status at Week 48
measure.description: The CGI-C was used to assess the participant's overall condition on a 7-point scale, using the status markers "very much improved, much improved, slightly improved, no change, slightly worse, much worse or very much worse" at Week 48 as compared to baseline.
measure.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment. Included in the analysis are only those subjects for whom an efficacy assessment was completed at Week 48.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline at Week 48 in 95th Percentile Stride Velocity
outcome.description: Stride velocity was recorded with the ActiMyo device in a subset of the overall study population. The ActiMyo device measures the daily movement and activity levels of the participant. The device consists of two sensors worn on each ankle. A higher velocity reflects a better outcome. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement.
outcome.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo solution subcutaneously (SC) on specified days of the 48-week double-blind (DB) period. Following the DB period participants received low dose or high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

measure.description: Stride velocity was recorded with the ActiMyo device in a subset of the overall study population. The ActiMyo device measures the daily movement and activity levels of the participant. The device consists of two sensors worn on each ankle. A higher velocity reflects a better outcome. A positive change from baseline indicates an improvement.
measure.population: Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all enrolled participants who received a randomization treatment assignment.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events (AEs)
outcome.description: An adverse event is any untoward medical occurrence in a subject administered a pharmaceutical product and which does not necessarily have to have a causal relationship with the treatment. An adverse event can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding, for example), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a pharmaceutical product, whether or not considered related to the pharmaceutical product. Preexisting conditions which worsen during a study are also considered as adverse events.
outcome.time_frame: During DB period (48 weeks) and Whole study (up to approximately 34 months)
outcome.population: Safety population included all enrolled participants who received at least 1 dose of study therapy. Data are presented for the arms in the DB period as well as for all RO7239361-treated participants in the whole study.

group.title: Placebo DB
group.description: Participants received matching placebo solution subcutaneously (SC) on specified days of the 48-week double-blind (DB) period.

group.title: RO7239361 Low Dose DB
group.description: Participants received low dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period.

group.title: RO7239361 High Dose DB
group.description: Participants received high dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period.

group.title: RO7239361 Low Dose
group.description: Participants received low dose RO7239361 SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received low dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

group.title: RO7239361 High Dose Whole Study
group.description: Participants received high dose SC on specified days of the 48-week DB period. Following the DB period participants received high dose RO7239361 on specified days for up to 192 weeks during the open-label period followed by 24 weeks of follow-up.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events (AEs)
measure.description: An adverse event is any untoward medical occurrence in a subject administered a pharmaceutical product and which does not necessarily have to have a causal relationship with the treatment. An adverse event can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding, for example), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a pharmaceutical product, whether or not considered related to the pharmaceutical product. Preexisting conditions which worsen during a study are also considered as adverse events.
measure.population: Safety population included all enrolled participants who received at least 1 dose of study therapy. Data are presented for the arms in the DB period as well as for all RO7239361-treated participants in the whole study.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With AEs Leading to Discontinuation
outcome.description: An adverse event is any untoward medical occurrence in a subject administered a pharmaceutical product and which does not necessarily have to have a causal relationship with the treatment. An adverse event can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding, for example), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a pharmaceutical product, whether or not considered related to the pharmaceutical product. Preexisting conditions which worsen during a study are also considered as adverse events. Reported here is the number of participants with AEs that led to study discontinuation.
outcome.time_frame: During DB period (48 weeks) and Whole study (up to approximately 34 months)
outcome.population: Safety population included all enrolled participants who received at least 1 dose of study therapy. Data are presented for the arms in the DB period as well as for all RO7239361-treated participants in the whole study.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The Study being conducted under this Agreement is part of the Overall Study. Investigator is free to publish in reputable journals or to present at professional conferences the results of the Study, but only after the first publication or presentation that involves the Overall Study. The Sponsor may request that Confidential Information be deleted and/or the publication be postponed in order to protect the Sponsor's intellectual property rights.
